Introduction

Hyper-IgE syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency syndrome in which impaired Janus activated kinaseâ€“signal transducer and activator of transcription (JAK-STAT) signaling between T-helper cells and neutrophils prevents neutrophils from responding to infection.  Patients have recurrent skin and sinopulmonary infections, eczema-like dermatitis, and characteristic physical features (eg, coarse facial features, hyperextensible joints).

Pathogenesis



Neutrophils respond to infection through a multistep process that begins when circulating neutrophils extravasate and migrate to the site of infection (ie, chemotaxis) (

figure 1
).  A disruption in any step of this process can lead to persistent and/or recurrent infections, as seen in hyper-IgE syndrome.



Patients with hyper-IgE syndrome have a normal number of neutrophils capable of adhering, transmigrating, engulfing, and lysing pathogens.  However, chemotaxis requires cytokine signaling.  For example, T-helper cell type 17 (Th17) secretes IL-17 to induce neutrophil proliferation and chemotaxis in response to infection.  Hyper-IgE syndrome is most commonly caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in the gene for STAT3, a cytoplasmic protein involved in the JAK-STAT pathway.  Impaired JAK-STAT intracellular signaling prevents Th17 cells from secreting IL-17, which prevents neutrophil chemotaxis.  Therefore, abscesses in patients with hyper-IgE syndrome are often described as "cold" because they lack the classic signs of an inflammatory response (eg, erythema, tenderness, warmth).



In addition, IL-17 induces the production of antimicrobial peptides by respiratory epithelial cells and keratinocytes.  Lack of these antimicrobial peptides explains in part the recurrent skin and sinopulmonary infections seen in hyper-IgE syndrome.



The exact mechanism between impaired JAK-STAT signaling and the other clinical features of hyper-IgE syndrome (eg, eczema-like dermatitis, skeletal abnormalities, elevated serum IgE) is less well-understood but is likely related to other cytokines involved in JAK-STAT signaling (eg, IL-6, IL-10).  Therefore, the elevated serum IgE level is merely a feature, instead of the pathogenesis, of hyper-IgE syndrome, as the name implies.

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of hyper-IgE syndrome varies and involves multiple systems.  The most common features include:



  • Eczema-like dermatitis:  Patients typically have a papular rash on the scalp and face that spreads to the trunk and buttocks in the first few weeks of life.  The papules often evolve into pustules that rupture and form a crust.  The affected skin is intensely pruritic, likely due to an immune response (eg, mast cells releasing histamine) to cutaneous staphylococci and Candida, and may become lichenified over time.  The rash is rarely associated with other signs of atopy (eg, allergic rhinitis, asthma), and secondary bacterial and fungal infections are common.
  • Recurrent skin infections:  Beginning in early infancy, recurrent skin infections typically develop, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus and Candida albicans.  Infections are not typically associated with inflammation due to impaired neutrophil chemotaxis.  Patients are typically afebrile and well-appearing due to an impaired inflammatory response.
  • Recurrent sinopulmonary infections:  Infections can occur due to a variety of pathogens, including S aureus, C albicans, and gram-negative bacteria (eg, Pseudomonas).  Because of impaired neutrophil chemotaxis, patients can develop severe infections with only mild symptoms.  Recurrent pulmonary infections can lead to life-threatening complications (eg, bronchiectasis, bronchopleural fistulae, pneumatoceles).
  • Connective tissue and skeletal abnormalities:  Patients have characteristic facial features, including broad nasal base and bridge, frontal bossing, and deep-set eyes.  Over time, soft tissue thickening gives the skin a doughy appearance, often referred to as "coarse facies."  Patients typically retain the primary teeth, which require extraction.  Scoliosis, osteoporosis (ie, pathologic fractures), and joint flexibility are common.

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected hyper-IgE syndrome, initial laboratory evaluation includes:



  • Quantitative immunoglobulins:  Show elevated serum IgE levels that do not correlate with specific allergens or disease severity.  Other immunoglobulin levels are typically normal.
  • Complete blood count with differential:  Shows eosinophilia (ie, >40% of total white blood cell count).  The total white blood cell count is usually normal, even during infection, when leukocytosis is expected.  Although not required for diagnosis, lymphocyte subset analysis shows a decreased Th17 cell count.  Eosinophilic infiltrates are often found in the skin and sputum of patients with recurrent skin and sinopulmonary infections.


Clinical and laboratory findings should be confirmed with genetic testing identifying a mutation in the STAT3 gene.

Differential diagnosis



  • ChÃ©diak-Higashi syndrome:  A lysosomal trafficking disorder that presents in early childhood with recurrent infections (eg, Staphylococcus, Streptococcus) and oculocutaneous albinism, not eczema-like dermatitis.
  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency:  Characterized by impaired leukocyte adhesion and extravasation, leading to recurrent skin infections without purulence and delayed wound healing.  Leukocytosis and neutrophilia, not eosinophilia, are characteristic.
  • Chronic granulomatous disease:  Characterized by impaired phagocytic intracellular killing, leading to recurrent infections and granuloma formation.  These patients do not have the physical features or elevated serum IgE levels seen in hyper-IgE syndrome.
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:  Characterized by a cytoskeletal defect in leukocytes and platelets.  Patients have recurrent infections and atopic dermatitis, similar to hyper-IgE syndrome.  However, patients develop microthrombocytopenia and bruising.

Management



Management of hyper-IgE syndrome is supportive, with frequent application of thick emollients to minimize exacerbations of eczema-like dermatitis and associated pruritus.  In addition, prophylactic antimicrobials (eg, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) and initiation of broad-spectrum antimicrobials at the earliest sign of infection help prevent infectious complications.  Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may be considered for patients with severe, recurrent infections.

Prognosis



Patients with hyper-IgE syndrome have a lifelong risk for serious infections.  Complications of recurrent pulmonary infections (eg, bronchiectasis, pneumatocele) are the most significant cause of morbidity and mortality.  Similar to other immunodeficiency syndromes, patients with hyper-IgE syndrome are at increased risk for certain autoimmune conditions and malignancies, especially non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Summary



Hyper-IgE syndrome (
